statement:
If $x$ is a nilpotent element of a ring with unity 1 (which may be 0),
then the sum $1\!+\!x$ is a unit of the ring.

If $x=0$, then $1\!+\!x=1$, which is a unit. Thus, we may assume that
$x \neq 0$.

Since $x$ is nilpotent, there is a positive integer $n$ such that
$x^n=0$. We multiply $1\!+\!x$ by another ring element:
$$\begin{aligned}
(1\!+\!x)\cdot\sum_{j=0}^{n-1}(-1)^jx^j
&=& \sum_{j=0}^{n-1}(-1)^jx^j\!+\!\sum_{k=0}^{n-1}(-1)^kx^{k+1}\\
&=& \sum_{j=0}^{n-1}(-1)^jx^j\!-\!\sum_{k=1}^n(-1)^kx^k\\
&=& 1\!+\!\sum_{j=1}^{n-1}(-1)^jx^j\!-\!\sum_{k=1}^{n-1}(-1)^kx^k\!-\!(-1)^nx^n\\
&=& 1\!+\!0\!+\!0\\
&=& 1\end{aligned}$$

(Note that the summations include the term $(-1)^0x^0$, which is why
$x=0$ is excluded from this case.)

The reversed multiplication gives the same result. Therefore, $1\!+\!x$
has a multiplicative inverse and thus is a unit.
